"Thick As A Brick (Part 1)" Really don't mind if you sit this one out. My words but a whisper your deafness a SHOUT. I may make you feel but I can't make you think. Your sperm's in the gutter your love's in the sink. So you ride yourselves over the fields and you make all your animal deals and your wise men don't know how it feels to be thick as a brick. And the sand-castle virtues are all swept away in the tidal destruction the moral melee. The elastic retreat rings the close of play as the last wave uncovers the newfangled way. But your new shoes are worn at the heels and your suntan does rapidly peel and your wise men don't know how it feels to be thick as a brick. And the love that I feel is so far away: I'm a bad dream that I just had today and you shake your head and say it's a shame. Spin me back down the years and the days of my youth. Draw the lace and black curtains and shut out the whole truth. Spin me down the long ages: let them sing the song. See there! A son is born and we pronounce him fit to fight. There are black-heads on his shoulders, and he pees himself in the night. We'll make a man of him, put him to trade teach him to play Monopoly and how to sing in the rain. The Poet and the Painter casting shadows on the water as the sun plays on the infantry returning from the sea. The do-er and the thinker: no allowance for the other as the failing light illuminates the mercenary's creed. The home fire burning: the kettle almost boiling but the master of the house is far away. The horses stamping, their warm breath clouding in the sharp and frosty morning of the day. And the poet lifts his pen while the soldier sheaths his sword. And the youngest of the family is moving with authority. Building castles by the sea, he dares the tardy tide to wash them all aside. The cattle quietly grazing at the grass down by the river where the swelling mountain water moves onward to the sea: the builder of the castles renews the age-old purpose and contemplates th

Message.Title: May/June Events
Message.Msg: Intel: June 3: Intel to release Haswell - In the final countdown stage. June 4: Computex Opening Keynote-Tom Kilroy, executive vice president and general manager, Intel's Sales and Marketing Group, will deliver a keynote on Intel's vision for continued innovation to reinvent people's computing experiences across a range of devices. June 4: Computex-Computing Reinvented Satellite Event and Media Q&A-Kirk Skaugen, senior vice president and general manager of the PC Client Group, will host the computing reinvented satellite event where he'll demonstrate and provide details on the new experiences delivered by 4th generation Intel Core processor-based Ultrabooks, laptops, desktops and all-in-one devices. June 5: Computex-Mobile and Communications Satellite Event and Media Q&A-Hermann Eul, VP/GM, Mobile and Communications Group, will host a satellite event to showcase the growing number of tablets for Windows and Android, smartphones and other ultra-mobile devices with Intel Inside. June 4-6: Dell Enterprise Forum-Enterprise Solutions Keynote: Built for Where Business Is Going June 10-14: Apple's WWDC - Macs about to get a major upgrade thanks to Intel’s new “Iris” graphics processors? June 26-28: Microsoft's Build Developer Conference - Rumors of next Surface Pro announcement ARM: None. And after the disaster at investor's day, they are not likely to schedule any more. Stock dropped 9 percent...

Message.Title: Good read on HFT
Message.Msg: seekingalphaDOTcom/article/1454351-high-frequency-trading-harmful-or-helpful?source=email_portfolio&ifp=0
You kinda remind me of the bully at school. Wallis is just fine.

The article is good. The author seems to have a medium level knowledge of HFT and his writing should be taken as only part of the picture. He did not know that exchanges pay the HFT a rebate for trades to lure the liquidity. That is an important part of the picture. The video he cites as a JNJ video is titled MRK video. Just a minor error but is one clue of the care he takes. There are several other similar NANEX videos on Youtube. I really like colorful displays like these. 4th of July reminders. AUTHOR FROM COMMENTS SECTION: "Thanks for that insight! I didn't know that HFT firms were rebated for their flow. That makes a whole lot of sense as to why they trade so much and are so consistently profitable. Thanks again, Elliott " In my limited reading on HFT, there was also an issue of the HFT being able to see the trade books. If he can see the trade books, he can get more information about the state of the market. If the HFT firms are getting rebates on both sides of the trade, they can buy and sell in the middle and they can see SELL or BUY orders piling up. If they see a LIMIT ORDER that is converted to a MARKET ORDER when the price drops, they can pressure the price into that limit order by shorting and then cover their shorts from the lower prices. IMO, being able to view the order book is a key part of the equation. HFT does provide liquidity but at some level of risk. thanks

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: It's encouraging that the damage has been contained after Wednesday's key reversal day. With the exception of the DJ Utility index all the major averages remained well above their respective 50-day moving averages, which is a positive and keeps the major trend intact. Increased volatility is probably back as investors try to interpret the Fed speak and what taking away Bernanke's backstop could do for the market. There continues to be a swarm of investors that are waiting to get in to this market at lower prices which should limit the downside. Although stronger economic data could hasten the tapering of QE, the trick remains how to exit the arena and leave stocks standing on their own two feet.

Hey, keep up the great work Wallis!

So the short position will take about 5 days to cover at average volume? Though the real issue here for the short sellers is how liquid is intel's float. My guess is that only 20% of the float is generally in play at any given time, about 1 billion shares. The rest (80%) being held by long and dividend seeking investors. Not to mention intels own buy back. So lately the average volume has been dropping dramatically. My guess is that most of the short position is at about $22, margin calls wont start come into play unless intel rises above $25. Irrespective, effectively near 20% of the active float my guess is short.

Short interest started climbing by 1mil shares per day or about 10mil shares each half month reporting period. It started climbing over a year ago but I cannot find more than 1 year history. I think the average price of shorts is a little higher than $22 but that would be just my impression. Intel contracts with a company to do their buy backs. Read about the Lehman Bros lawsuit against Intel to see an example of their instructions. Intel contract buys based on average volume and price over a period of time. Options are likely an easy exit. There are a million combinations. The excess short is about 150mil shares. The remaining shorts are probably part of the INVERSE ETF like SOXS, QLD, SDS, ... Value investors? The funny thing is that conservative funds in their search for yield are one of the major sources of shares to loan for shorting. It will be interesting to watch. I watched the shorts load up but I don't think there will be a squeeze. I WAS surprised at the small drop in shorts and the 17% increase in price.

Don't forget shorts have to find $50m cash in the next couple of weeks. Even lent out shares would be returning a premium above what the stock would pay in divvy, may be the borrow agreement includes interest fees and full payment of Dividend?

Message.Title: ANOTHER 10" ANDROID TABLET INTEL WIN: ASUS ME302C
Message.Msg: phonearenaDOTcom/news/Asus-ME302C-tablet-leaks-in-bechmarks-has-Intel-Atom-processor_id42382 "So, it looks like the Asus Fonepad won't be the last Intel-powered Android tablet by Asus. There's a new, yet-to-be-announced model in tow, as revealed by the data in these benchmark results. Known as the Asus ME302C, it is a member ot the EeePad family, presumably with a screen of (or around) 10 inches, given its display resolution of 1920 by 1200 pixels." [So far, Clover Trail+ will be inside the following devices: TABLETS: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 Acer W3-810 (leaked on Amazon) Asus ME302C * Remember these devices have potential to run both Windows 8 and Android. Dual boot for both these OS is possible too. SMARTPHONES: Lenovo K900 (launched already) ZTE Grand X2 ZTE Geek phone Asus Phone with CloverTrail+ ]

Topic.Title: ANOTHER 10" ANDROID TABLET INTEL WIN: ASUS ME302C

Message.Msg: With Silvermont (Bay Trail, Merrifield) products available by holiday season shopping, Intel looking like they can very quickly capture tablet and smartphone market share. Hardware makers can't ignore the following stats: MERRIFIELD Dual core (1W) at same performance use 2.4x less power than competition. At same power, performs 1.6x the speed of competition. BAY TRAIL Intel's quad core beauties either giving twice the performance at the same power level or 4.3x less power at the same performance

Message.Title: Posting Culture
Message.Msg: Thanks to all who have found some usefulness in my posts. I do have some thoughts about the culture of posting on Yahoo. 1.) Everyone has a right to their opinion and to post it up unless it is obscene or abusive. Or unless it constitutes bullying, harassment or stalking. Apparently Yahoo pretty much agrees with this. You are also not allowed to use the boards for commercial promotion. 2.) No one has a right to credibility. Credibility has to be earned. Many posters think that their opinion is credible simply because it is their opinion. It's almost never the case. 3.) Some posters believe it is their god-given right to be the board moderator. It's not. 4.) Some posters engage in nothing other than content-free posting. It is difficult to believe that these posters are anything other than paid shills of an Intel competitor, mentally incompetent, or psychologically incompetent. 5.) Credibility is earned by informative posts, stated in a lucid manner with supporting facts, logic and thoughtfulness. Credibility is enhanced by good written expression and an advanced sense of humor. 6.) The use of multiple IDs rarely does anything but destroy credibility. Why Yahoo allows it is a mystery to me. People with nothing to hide don't need multiple IDs. People with hidden agendas do need multiple IDs. 7.) Talking smack is an art. It needs to be informative and funny and well-written in order to be well-received. Those who think an angry, bile-fueled post is effective smack are totally and completely wrong. It just points out that they are too incompetent to effectively talk smack and that they shouldn't bother. Bad smack erodes credibility. 8.) Anger is not an argument. Just because a poster is angry it doesn't mean that he or she has an effective rebuttal to whatever is causing the anger. 9.) Calling people names is not an argument. It is unfortunately the only kind of post some people are capable of. 10.) It's not about the past - it's about the future.
Love your posts Wallis! Please don't ever stop sharing your knowledge of Intel with us. You are an extremely valuable asset here. Thank you!
